candidates.title: Release Vulkano 0.28
candidates.body:
A lot of breaking changes have accumulated already, I think this may be a good moment for a new release?

I've renamed the changelog file because now that vk-sys is gone, there is only one changelog, so there is no need to make the name longer.

candidates.body:

with this:
```markdown
- **Breaking** Updated to ash 0.35, half 1.8, smallvec 1.7, winit 0.26, raw-window-handle 0.4.
```
And add:
```markdown
- **Breaking** `ColorSpace::DciP3Linear` is renamed to `DisplayP3Linear` to match an equivalent change in the Vulkan naming.
- Updated vk.xml to 1.2.203.
```

Just keeping up to date. vk-parse had an update that fixed some errors, so an updated vk.xml can be used now too.

candidates.title: Implement VertexMember for nalgebra Vectors and Points
candidates.body:
1. [x] Describe in common words what is the purpose of this change, related
   Github Issues, and highlight important implementation aspects.

Implemented `VertexMember` for `nalgebra::Vector*<T>` and `nalgebra::Point*<T>` where * ∈ [1, 4]. 

Tested to be also working with `nalgebra_glm::Vec*`, since they are aliasing to the same types as `nalgebra::Vector*<f32>`.

64-bit floats won't work, but vulkano [doesn't](https://github.com/vulkano-rs/vulkano/blob/0ebf05f35d44c9742654cb6905abc69dbce619cb/vulkano/src/shader/mod.rs#L860) [seem to](https://github.com/vulkano-rs/vulkano/blob/0ebf05f35d44c9742654cb6905abc69dbce619cb/vulkano/src/shader/mod.rs#L887) support those anyway. (?)

Related: #1572, #1133, #1326

2. [x] Please put changelog entries **in the description of this Pull Request**
   if knowledge of this change could be valuable to users. No need to put the
   entries to the changelog directly, they will be transferred to the changelog
   files(`CHANGELOG_VULKANO.md` and `CHANGELOG_VK_SYS.md`)
   by maintainers right after the Pull Request merge.

    * Entries for Vulkano changelog:
        - `**Breaking** Breaking entry description.`
        - `Non-breaking entry description.`...

    * Entries for VkSys changelog:
        - `Entry 1.`
        - `Entry 2.`...

- Added support for nalgebra `Vector`s and `Point`s in vertex definitions.

3. [x] Run `cargo fmt` on the changes.

4. [ ] Make sure that the changes are covered by unit-tests.

Sorry, but I couldn't find the right place for tests.

If anyone could point that out, I'll add them.

5. [ ] Update documentation to reflect any user-facing changes - in this repository.

I have to apologize again, but I don't know where are the docs located either.

candidates.title: Fix undefined behaviour on external semaphore & image creation; Fix wrong device chosen on hybrid graphics
candidates.body:
Currently, whenever an exportable image or semaphore are created, the p_next structure used to specify the exportable handle types falls out of scope prematurely, which means segmentation faults can occur in certain situations, most likely when the stack memory is overwritten or is invalidated. 

In order to fix this, I've not only made sure to define these p_next structures in the appropriate scope, but I've also changed the implementations to use ash builders. This way, this issue would have been impossible to begin with, and two unsafe calls are removed.

@pwaller Please confirm this fixes the issues you encountered.

Using new functionality recently added in https://github.com/glium/glium/pull/1977, there is now UUID checking in the gl-interop example during physical device creation. This is useful since previously, if a computer had more than one graphics card or drivers, it was possible for Vulkan to choose a different device and/or driver than the GL context it is sharing resources with. This would result in undefined behaviour.

    * Entries for Vulkano changelog:
        - Fix undefined behaviour on external semaphore creation
        - Fix undefined behaviour on external image creation
        - Add uuid checking to gl-interop example

candidates.title: Upgrade to Rust 2021, update dependencies
candidates.body:
```markdown
- **Breaking** Updated to half 1.8, smallvec 1.7, winit 0.26, raw-window-handle 0.4.
```

```markdown
- Upgraded to Rust 2021.
```

Rust 2021 is a much smaller change than 2018 was, but it's still nice to have, especially for the ability to call `into_iter` on arrays properly now. This does mean that Vulkano 0.28 will require Rust 1.56 to compile. Because of how editions work, Vulkano can still be included in *other* projects using the 2018 or 2015 editions, compatibility is not broken.

candidates.title: Add shaderc-debug feature to Vulkano-shaders
candidates.body:
Changelog:
```markdown
- Added a `shaderc-debug` cargo feature to Vulkano-shaders, to emit debug information in the generated SPIR-V code.
```

Fixes #1742. @ProtoByter can you let me know if this implementation is sufficient for your purposes?

candidates.title: Fixes related to Image export & OpenGL Interop
candidates.body:
As a continuation of my previous work, where I added semaphore export  #1606, I've been working on adding the possibility to import Vulkano textures into OpenGL.

However, a few bugs in Vulkano currently prevent this functionality from working correctly:

- The memory builder was not populating its p_next structures at all, meaning memory was created neither as exportable or dedicated. I fixed this by getting rid of the old method of populating the p_next structures and instead using the Ash functionality.
- The exportable image must also be created with an additional structure [VkExternalImageCreateInfo](https://www.khronos.org/registry/vulkan/specs/1.2-extensions/man/html/VkExternalMemoryImageCreateInfo.html). I added a method to `UnsafeImage` which does this, and I used it accordingly in `AttachmentImage`.
- Issue 17 of OpenGL [EXT_external_objects](https://www.khronos.org/registry/OpenGL/extensions/EXT/EXT_external_objects.txt) demands that the mutable bit be set when some common extensions are present. I thus set it to true by default, but perhaps @hakolao can provide his input on whether this would make sense when sharing images with CUDA.

The result of these issues was heavy visual corruption on the AMD radeonsi driver. Interestingly, the Intel Iris driver does not suffer from visual corruptions even with the p_next creation structures missing.

The only remaining issue at the moment is a crash happening with the Intel Iris driver, when flushing the signal semaphore command from the OpenGL side. Running a debug version of the driver, it prints out `Failed to submit batchbuffer: Invalid argument`. Given that the driver does not pass the piglit `vk-semaphores-2` test, this is probably a problem within the Iris driver. I will submit a bug report to the Mesa repository.

I have created some [sample code](https://gist.github.com/fayalalebrun/8845ba4464af687895cf49ba96b105d6). This program draws to a shared texture with Glium from another thread, which is the drawn to the window by Vulkano. This texture oscillates between a black and green color. I'm interested to hear how well it works on Nvidia or with other Intel/AMD drivers.

Changelog:
- `Fix device memory builder not including p_next structures.`
- `Fix exportable image not created with VkExternalMemoryImageCreateInfo.`
- `Fix mutable bit not set on exportable image.`
[
Related Glium MR](https://github.com/glium/glium/pull/1965)

candidates.title: Add `DescriptorRequirements`
candidates.body:
Changelog:
```markdown
- **Breaking** Removed the `EntryPointAbstract` trait, which was unused.
- **Breaking** `ComputeEntryPoint` and `GraphicsEntryPoint` now hold a list of `DescriptorRequirements` instead of `DescriptorSetDesc`.
- **Breaking** Removed `union`, `union_multiple` and `ensure_compatible_with_shader` from `DescriptorSetDesc`, and `union` from `DescriptorDesc`. This is now handled by `DescriptorRequirements`.
- **Breaking** `DescriptorDesc::ensure_compatibility_with_shader` now takes `DescriptorRequirements` instead of another `DescriptorDesc`.
```
```markdown
- Added a new `DescriptorRequirements` type, which contains requirements imposed by a shader onto a descriptor and the resources bound to it.
  - `DescriptorDesc` can be created from `DescriptorRequirements` with the `From` trait.
  - `DescriptorSetDesc`s can be created from the requirements with the `from_requirement` constructor.
  - The descriptor requirements of a pipeline can be queried using a new `descriptor_requirements` method.
```

The purpose of this PR is to split the logic handling the requirements of shaders from the requirements of descriptor set layouts. My ultimate goal is to remove the `DescriptorDescTy` enum, and have requirements not related to descriptor set layouts be checked entirely from `DescriptorRequirements`. For this to happen, though, the requirements need to be available from the pipeline (which this PR implements), and validation code for command buffers needs to be able to retrieve the resources inside each descriptor set so that the resources can be validated against the requirements. Once this is done, it should be easier to implement per-resource updates and validation for push descriptors.

candidates.title: Lots of additional dynamic state, and some new pipeline state
candidates.body:
Changelog:
```markdown
- **Breaking** Major changes have been made to most parts of the graphics pipeline state.
  - Each state category is now provided by a separate type ending in `State` that lives in its own submodule of `pipeline`. Some of these were existing types that were renamed.
  - Most of the state-setting methods on `GraphicsPipelineBuilder` are deprecated. State is now set using a `_state` method, which is given one of the above state types.
- **Breaking** `DynamicStateMode` is replaced with a simple `bool`.
- **Breaking** The presence of dynamic state in the pipeline state is now expressed more explicitly with two new types, `StateMode` and `PartialStateMode`.
```
```markdown
- Added support for lots more dynamic state, most of which requires features or extensions to use.
- Added support for discard rectangles, in the `pipeline::discard_rectangle` module.
- Added support for line rasterization state, in the `pipeline::rasterization` module.
- Added support for color write enable state, in the `pipeline::color_blend` module.
- `GraphicsPipeline` now has methods to return each state object it was created with.
- `ash` has been updated to 0.33.3, which provides new features and extensions.
```

A very large PR this one! A lot of new states and features are added here. I decided to change how state is provided to `GraphicsPipelineBuilder` because there was starting to be too much of it, making the number of methods unreadably large. Now, instead, the builder simply takes state objects, each of which has a pure Vulkan equivalent. These state objects have convenience builder methods where appropriate, and sensible defaults. Examples of how this looks are in the... well, examples.

I added support for the `ext_extended_dynamic_state` and `ext_extended_dynamic_state2` extensions, which add "dynamicness" to a lot of existing pipeline state. In addition, I added three completely new pipeline states.

I hope I didn't miss out on any important/breaking changes. There's so many changes that it's hard to remember and list every little thing.

candidates.title: Add an interactive fractal example
candidates.body:
When diving into the Vulkano, I found that it can be a fairly slow process to wrap your head around all the concepts and how to use a renderer as a part of a project. The existing examples lack usable "wholes". E.g. deferred example is great, but it could even go as far to demonstrate something more useful rather than a triangle.

I've found that I prefer Vulkano over e.g wgpu and other libraries which is why I'd like to see nicer examples here.

I thought a simple interactive fractal explorer app made over the weekend could demonstrate Vulkano usage better inside a non-trivial project. Or just get new interested developers up to speed faster.

 It contains
 - Compute pipeline to calculate Mandelbrot and Julia fractals writing them to an image target
 - Graphics pipeline to draw the fractal image over a quad that covers the whole screen
 - Renderpass rendering that image over swapchain image
 - An organized `Renderer` with functionality good enough to copy to other projects
 - Simple `FractalApp` to handle runtime state
 - Simple Input system to interact with the application

Let me know if you prefer to keep the examples more "contained" around specific features or if I'm doing something wrong with vulkano here. I might consider adding more examples later.

Run in release mode or not, doesn't matter ;)
```
cargo run --bin interactive_fractal --release
cargo run --bin interactive_fractal
```

Usage:
```
    WASD: Pan view
    Scroll: Zoom in/out
    Space: Toggle between Mandelbrot and Julia
    Enter: Randomize color palette
    Equals/Minus: Increase/Decrease max iterations
    F: Toggle fullscreen
    Right mouse: Stop movement in Julia (mouse position determines c)
    Esc: Quit
```

Mandelbrot:

![mandelbrot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12234005/132993606-98725b09-8b8b-4bf9-88b8-8ab76c09370a.jpg)

Julia:

![julia](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12234005/132993706-1778b196-9245-4095-9549-032c5c095adc.jpg)

3. [x] Run `cargo fmt` on the changes.

4. [x] Make sure that the changes are covered by unit-tests.

5. [x] Update documentation to reflect any user-facing changes - in this repository.

candidates.title: Add auto-generated SPIR-V parsing
candidates.body:
Changelog
Remove this line, as the `spirv` crate isn't a dependency anymore:
```markdown
spirv_headers 1.5 > spirv 0.2 (crate was renamed and reversioned)
```
Add:
```markdown
- Added a `spirv` module to the main crate, which contains an auto-generated parser for SPIR-V files, and various other utilities that can be used to analyze shaders at runtime.
```

This PR adds SPIR-V parsing types and functions, auto-generated from the SPIR-V grammar document, which is included. The grammar is a JSON document, so this adds `serde_json` as a build-dependency for parsing. Some of the code has been moved from Vulkano-shaders and reworked. In particular, any parse errors that are reported will include information on the affected instruction, where the error happened, and the SPIR-V words of the instruction for debugging.

This is still a draft; the main parsing feature is now done, but I want to add code to gather some additional data from the module after it's parsed. Vulkano-shaders is also a bit of a mess, because it's only haphazardly converted to the new version. That needs to be fixed up too.


candidates.title: Add generation of `Format` to autogen
candidates.body:
Changelog:
```markdown
- **Breaking** Changes to `Format`:
  - `Format` variants are now all uppercase with underscores. This avoids interpretation problems where the underscore is significant for the meaning.
  - The `ty` method and the `FormatTy` enum are removed. They are replaced with the `NumericType` enum, which concerns itself only with the numeric representation and not with other properties. There are now three `type_*` methods to retrieve it, for colour, depth and stencil respectively.
  - The `planes` method now returns a slice containing the equivalent single-plane formats of each plane.
- **Breaking** The `ImageAccess` trait no longer has the `has_color`, `has_depth` and `has_stencil` methods. This information can be queried using the `aspects` or `type_*` methods of `Format`.
```
```markdown
- Non-breaking `Format` additions:
  - Formats and their metadata are now auto-generated from vk.xml. This significantly expands the support for YCbCr formats in particular.
  - The `compatibility` method returns an object that can be used to check the compatibility of two formats, explained [here](https://www.khronos.org/registry/vulkan/specs/1.2-extensions/html/chap43.html#formats-compatibility-classes).
  - The `components` method returns the number of bits in each colour component.
  - The `compression` method returns the compression scheme as a new enum, `CompressionType`.
  - The `requires_sampler_ycbcr_conversion` method returns whether the "sampler YCbCr conversion" must be enabled on an image view and sampler in order to use this format.
```

This PR adds a bunch of new formats that weren't supported yet, expands with new methods to query particular properties, and makes the existing methods more sane. I also wrote some better documentation for the `format` module. The ability to test for format compatibility allows #1666 to be solved, while all the other new methods fulfill other validity-testing use cases that are currently unimplemented. Sampler YCbCr conversion would certainly be worth a future PR.

The biggest, and perhaps most controversial breaking change is that the variants are now uppercase snake-cased like in C, rather than camelcased like is customary in Rust. But I found that this increases readability of the names a lot for complex formats. Take `G16_B16R16_2PLANE_420_UNORM` for example. In Rust camelcase, this would end up as `G16B16R162Plane420Unorm`, where the 16 and 2 are no longer separated, and no distinction is made between components in the same plane and components in different planes (G in one plane, B and R in the other). Similar problems occur with names like `G8B8G8R8_422_UNORM` and `PVRTC1_2BPP_UNORM_BLOCK`.

candidates.title: Generate full code directly in autogen instead of using macros
candidates.body:
Changelog:
```markdown
- The full Rust code is now generated from vk.xml by autogen directly, instead of using intermediate macros.
```

This implements what I proposed in #1654. I also changed a few implementation details: the code is generated using the `quote!` macro now instead of directly writing text to the file, and it's then formatted by `rustfmt` if it's available.
